thread.title: Arsene Wenger Won't Be Happy With Where He Has To Sit Against Chelsea
thread.title_full: Arsene Wenger Won't Be Happy With Where He Has To Sit Against Chelsea

title: Arsene Wenger Won't Be Happy With Where He Has To Sit Against Chelsea
text:
Arsene Wenger Won't Be Happy With Where He Has To Sit Against Chelsea Thu Feb 02 2017 15:36:49   15:36:49 GMT+0000 (GMT) Josh Lawless Josh Lawless in football 
Arsene Wenger won't be best pleased about where he has to sit and watch his side's game against Chelsea from at Stamford Bridge on Saturday. 
The Arsenal boss is serving the third game of his four-match touchline ban after pushing fourth official Anthony Taylor following his annoyance at a referee decision against Burnley at the Emirates. 
Typically, managers watch the game from the directors box but at Chelsea this weekend, that won't be the case for Wenger. 
According to the Evening Standard , Wenger will be forced to sit with the Chelsea fans for the big game at Stamford Bridge. 
They report that the directors box at Chelsea is in a different spot and it would be incredibly tough for Wenger to carry out duties such as media interviews and team talks from the West Stand and so other arrangements have been made. 
Instead, Wenger will be sat in the East Stand, in the middle tier. 
Inevitably, the 67-year old doesn't exactly have a great relationship with Chelsea fans and so plans are being ironed to ensure Wenger's safety in the upcoming game - with stewards set to usher him to and from his seat. 
There is also talk that Arsenal will be bringing their own security, who will sit with Wenger throughout the course of the game. It's unclear whether they are also there to give him tactical advice. 
It's not certainly not ideal for Wenger, who had an interesting experience a couple of years back in the stands at Old Trafford. 
The former Monaco boss famously booted a plastic bottle after seeing his side's goal chalked off for offside and then had to stand in the middle of a group of United fans. 
Relive that memorable moment with Gordon Strachan's brilliant narration here:
